line.token: * PHPMailer - PHP email creation and transport class.
* @license http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/lesser.html GNU Lesser General Public License
* @note This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful - WITHOUT
* ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of MERCHANTABILITY or
* PHPMailer - PHP email creation and transport class.
* The character set of the message.
* The MIME Content-type of the message.
* Holds the most recent mailer error message.
* The From email address for the message.
* The From name of the message.
* The Sender email (Return-Path) of the message.
* If not empty, will be sent via -f to sendmail or as 'MAIL FROM' in smtp mode.
* If empty, it will be set to either From or Sender.
* @deprecated Email senders should never set a return-path header;
* it's the receiver's job (RFC5321 section 4.4), so this no longer does anything.
* An HTML or plain text message body.
* This body can be read by mail clients that do not have HTML email
* Clients that can read HTML will view the normal Body.
* Only supported in simple alt or alt_inline message types
* To generate iCal events, use the bundled extras/EasyPeasyICS.php class or iCalcreator
* The complete compiled MIME message body.
* The complete compiled MIME message headers.
* Extra headers that createHeader() doesn't fold in.
* Word-wrap the message body to this number of chars.
* Set to 0 to not wrap. A useful value here is 78, for RFC2822 section 2.1.1 compliance.
* Which method to use to send mail.
* The path to the sendmail program.
* Whether mail() uses a fully sendmail-compatible MTA.
* Useful if the SMTP class is not in the PHP include path.
* @deprecated Should not be needed now there is an autoloader.
* The email address that a reading confirmation should be sent to.
* The hostname to use in Message-Id and Received headers
* An ID to be used in the Message-Id header.
* If empty, a unique id will be generated.
* The message Date to be used in the Date header.
* If empty, the current date will be added.
* Either a single hostname or multiple semicolon-delimited hostnames.
* You can also specify a different port
* for each host by using this format: [hostname:port]
* You can also specify encryption type, for example:
* Hosts will be tried in order.
* @TODO Why is this needed when the SMTP class takes care of it?
* The SMTP HELO of the message.
* Uses the Username and Password properties.
* Options are LOGIN (default), PLAIN, NTLM, CRAM-MD5
* The SMTP server timeout in seconds.
* Default of 5 minutes (300sec) is from RFC2821 section 4.5.3.2
* * `echo` Output plain-text as-is, appropriate for CLI

* * `html` Output escaped, line breaks converted to `
`, appropriate for browser output
* * `error_log` Output to error log as configured in php.ini
* Alternatively, you can provide a callable expecting two params: a message string and the debug level:
* Whether to keep SMTP connection open after each message.
* If this is set to true then to close the connection
* requires an explicit call to smtpClose().
* Whether to split multiple to addresses into multiple messages
* or send them all in one message.
* Storage for addresses when SingleTo is enabled.
* @TODO This should really not be public
* Whether to generate VERP addresses on send.
* Only applicable when sending via SMTP.
* Whether to allow sending messages with an empty body.
* @note The default remains "\n". We force CRLF where we know
* it must be used via self::CRLF.
* Usually the email address used as the source of the email
* Used if your key is encrypted.
* The function that handles the result of the send email action.
* It is called out by send() for each email sent.
* Value can be any php callable: http://www.php.net/is_callable
* boolean $result result of the send action
* string $to email address of the recipient
* What to put in the X-Mailer header.
* Options: An empty string for PHPMailer default, whitespace for none, or a string to use
* An instance of the SMTP sender class.
* The array of reply-to names and addresses.
* An array of all kinds of addresses.
* The most recent Message-ID (including angular brackets).
* The array of MIME boundary strings.
* The S/MIME password for the key.
* Used only if the key is encrypted.
* Whether to throw exceptions for errors.
* Error severity: message only, continue processing.
* Error severity: message, likely ok to continue processing.
* Error severity: message, plus full stop, critical error reached.
* @param boolean $exceptions Should we throw external exceptions?
* Call mail() in a safe_mode-aware fashion.
* Also, unless sendmail_path points to sendmail (or something that
* claims to be sendmail), don't pass params (not a perfect fix,
//Check overloading of mail function to avoid double-encoding
* Output debugging info via user-defined method.
* Only generates output if SMTP debug output is enabled (@see SMTP::$do_debug).
//Cleans up output a bit for a better looking, HTML-safe output
* Sets message type to HTML or plain.
* Send messages using PHP's mail() function.
* @return boolean true on success, false if address already used
* @note: This function works with the SMTP mailer on win32, not with the "mail" mailer.
* @return boolean true on success, false if address already used
* @note: This function works with the SMTP mailer on win32, not with the "mail" mailer.
* @return boolean true on success, false if address already used
* Add an address to one of the recipient arrays.
* Addresses that have been added already return false, but do not throw exceptions
* @param string $address The email address to send to
* @return boolean true on success, false if address already used or invalid in some way
* Set the From and FromName properties.
* @param boolean $auto Whether to also set the Sender address, defaults to true
* Return the Message-ID header of the last email.
* Technically this is the value from the last time the headers were created,
* but it's also the message ID of the last sent message except in
* Check that a string looks like an email address.
* @param string $address The email address to check
* @param string $patternselect A selector for the validation pattern to use :
* * `pcre8` Use the squiloople.com pattern, requires PCRE > 8.0, PHP >= 5.3.2, 5.2.14;
* * `php` Use PHP built-in FILTER_VALIDATE_EMAIL; same as pcre8 but does not allow 'dotless' domains;
* * `html5` Use the pattern given by the HTML5 spec for 'email' type form input elements.
* * `noregex` Don't use a regex: super fast, really dumb.
//Check this constant first so it works when extension_loaded() is disabled by safe mode
//This pattern can get stuck in a recursive loop in PCRE <= 8.0.2
//Filter_var appeared in PHP 5.2.0 and does not require the PCRE extension
* Uses the same RFC5322 regex on which FILTER_VALIDATE_EMAIL is based, but allows dotless domains.
* Feel free to use and redistribute this code. But please keep this copyright notice.
//An older regex that doesn't need a recent PCRE
* This is the pattern used in the HTML5 spec for validation of 'email' type form input elements.
//Check the address is 3 chars or longer and contains an @ that's not the first or last char
* Create a message and send it.
* Uses the sending method specified by $Mailer.
* @return boolean false on error - See the ErrorInfo property for details of the error.
// Set whether the message is multipart/alternative
// Refuse to send an empty message unless we are specifically allowing it
// To capture the complete message when using mail(), create
// an extra header list which createHeader() doesn't fold in
* Send the email via the selected mechanism
// Choose the mailer and send through it
* Send mail using the PHP mail() function.
* Get an instance to use for SMTP operations.
* Override this function to load your own SMTP implementation
* Returns false if there is a bad MAIL FROM, RCPT, or DATA input.
* Uses the PHPMailerSMTP class by default.
* @see PHPMailer::getSMTPInstance() to use a different class.
// Attempt to send to all recipients
// Only send the DATA command if we have viable recipients
// Create error message for any bad addresses
* Initiate a connection to an SMTP server.
* Returns false if the operation failed.
* @param array $options An array of options compatible with stream_context_create()
// The host string prefix can temporarily override the current setting for SMTPSecure
// If it's not specified, the default value is used
// Can't have SSL and TLS at once
// We must resend HELO after tls negotiation
// We must have connected, but then failed TLS or Auth, so close connection nicely
// If we get here, all connection attempts have failed, so close connection hard
// As we've caught all exceptions, just report whatever the last one was
* Close the active SMTP session if one exists.
* Set the language for error messages.
* Returns false if it cannot load the language file.
* @param string $langcode ISO 639-1 2-character language code (e.g. French is "fr")
* @param string $lang_path Path to the language file directory, with trailing separator (slash)
// Define full set of translatable strings in English
'SMTP Error: Could not connect to SMTP host.'
'You must provide at least one recipient email address.'
// Calculate an absolute path so it can work if CWD is not here
// There is no English translation file
// Make sure language file path is readable
// This way we'll never have missing translations.
// Returns false if language not found
* Get the array of strings for the current language.
* where each recipient is a 2-element indexed array with element 0 containing an address
* and element 1 containing a name, like:
* Format an address for use in a message header.
* @param array $addr A 2-element indexed array, element 0 containing an address, element 1 containing a name
* For use with mailers that do not automatically perform wrapping
* @param integer $length The line length to wrap to
* @param boolean $qp_mode Whether to run in Quoted-Printable mode
// If utf-8 encoding is used, we will need to make sure we don't
// split multibyte characters when we wrap
* Find the last character boundary prior to $maxLength in a utf-8
* @param integer $maxLength find last character boundary prior to this length
// Found start of encoded character byte within $lookBack block.
// Check the encoded byte value (the 2 chars after the '=')
// If the encoded char was found at pos 0, it will fit
// otherwise reduce maxLength to start of the encoded char
// First byte of a multi byte character
// Reduce maxLength to split at start of character
// Middle byte of a multi byte character, look further back
// To be created automatically by mail()
// sendmail and mail() extract Cc from the header before sending
// sendmail and mail() extract Bcc from the header before sending
* Get the message MIME type headers.
// RFC1341 part 5 says 7bit is assumed if not specified
// RFC 2045 section 6.4 says multipart MIME parts may only use 7bit, 8bit or binary CTE
// The only remaining alternatives are quoted-printable and base64, which are both 7bit compatible
* Returns an empty string on failure.
// @TODO would be nice to use php://temp streams here, but need to wrap for PHP < 5.1
* Return the start of a message boundary.
// RFC1341 part 5 says 7bit is assumed if not specified
* Return the end of a message boundary.
* PHPMailer only supports some preset message types,
* Add an attachment from a path on the filesystem.
* Returns false if the file could not be found or read.
// If a MIME type is not specified, try to work it out from the file name
* Attach all file, string, and binary attachments to the message.
* Returns an empty string on failure.
// Check if it is a valid disposition_filter
// RFC1341 part 5 says 7bit is assumed if not specified
// If a filename contains any of these chars, it should be quoted,
// Fixes a warning in IETF's msglint MIME checker
// Allow for bypassing the Content-Disposition header totally
* Encode a file attachment in requested format.
* Returns an empty string on failure.
* @param string $path The full path to the file
* @param string $encoding The encoding to use; one of 'base64', '7bit', '8bit', 'binary', 'quoted-printable'
//Doesn't exist in PHP 5.4, but we don't need to check because
* Encode a string in requested format.
* Returns an empty string on failure.
* @param string $encoding The encoding to use; one of 'base64', '7bit', '8bit', 'binary', 'quoted-printable'
// Make sure it ends with a line break
* Picks shortest of Q, B, quoted-printable or none.
// Can't use addslashes as we don't know the value of magic_quotes_sybase
// There are no chars that need encoding
// Try to select the encoding which should produce the shortest output
// More than a third of the content will need encoding, so B encoding will be most efficient
// Use a custom function which correctly encodes and wraps long
// multibyte strings without breaking lines within a character
* Check if a string contains multi-byte characters.
* @param string $str multi-byte text to wrap encode
// Assume no multibytes (we can't handle without mbstring functions anyway)
* Does a string contain any 8-bit chars (in any charset)?
* Encode and wrap long multibyte strings for mail headers
* without breaking lines within a character.
* Adapted from a function by paravoid
* @param string $str multi-byte text to wrap encode
* @param string $linebreak string to use as linefeed/end-of-line
// Each line must have length <= 75, including $start and $end
* Encode a string in quoted-printable format.
* @param integer $line_max Number of chars allowed on a line before wrapping
// Use native function if it's available (>= PHP5.3)
// Fall back to a pure PHP implementation
* Backward compatibility wrapper for an old QP encoding function that was removed.
* Encode a string using Q encoding.
* @param string $position Where the text is going to be used, see the RFC for what that means
// There should not be any EOL in the string
// for this reason we build the $pattern without including delimiters and []
// Replace every high ascii, control, =, ? and _ characters
// If the string contains an '=', make sure it's the first thing we replace
// Replace every spaces to _ (more readable than =20)
* Add a string or binary attachment (non-filesystem).
* This method can be used to attach ascii or binary data,
* such as a BLOB record from a database.
// If a MIME type is not specified, try to work it out from the file name
* Add an embedded (inline) attachment from a file.
* This can include images, sounds, and just about any other document type.
* These differ from 'regular' attachments in that they are intended to be
* displayed inline with the message, not just attached for download.
* This is used in HTML messages that embed the images
* the HTML refers to using the $cid value.
* @param string $cid Content ID of the attachment; Use this to reference
* the content when using an embedded image in HTML.
* @return boolean True on successfully adding an attachment
// If a MIME type is not specified, try to work it out from the file name
* This can include images, sounds, and just about any other document type.
* Be sure to set the $type to an image type for images:
* JPEG images use 'image/jpeg', GIF uses 'image/gif', PNG uses 'image/png'.
* @param string $cid Content ID of the attachment; Use this to reference
* the content when using an embedded image in HTML.
* @return boolean True on successfully adding an attachment
// If a MIME type is not specified, try to work it out from the name
* Check if an inline attachment is present.
* Check if an attachment (non-inline) is present.
* Check if this message has an alternative body set.
* Clear all filesystem, string, and binary attachments.
* Add an error message to the error container.
// Set the time zone to whatever the default is to avoid 500 errors
// Will default to UTC if it's not set properly in php.ini
* Get an error message in the current language.
* @return boolean True if an error did occur.
* Ensure consistent line endings in a string.
* Changes every end of line from CRLF, CR or LF to $this->LE.
* $name value can be overloaded to contain
* Create a message from an HTML string.
* Automatically makes modifications for inline images and backgrounds
* and creates a plain-text version by converting the HTML.
* Overwrites any existing values in $this->Body and $this->AltBody
* @param boolean|callable $advanced Whether to use the internal HTML to text converter
* or your own custom converter @see html2text()
// Convert data URIs into embedded images
// Do not change urls for absolute images (thanks to corvuscorax)
// Convert all message body line breaks to CRLF, makes quoted-printable encoding work much better
'To view this email message, open it in a program that understands HTML!'
* Convert an HTML string into plain text.
* Note - older versions of this function used a bundled advanced converter
* which was been removed for license reasons in #232
* @param string $html The HTML text to convert
* @param boolean|callable $advanced Any boolean value to use the internal converter,
* or provide your own callable for custom conversion.
* Get the MIME type for a file extension.
* Map a file name to a MIME type.
* Defaults to 'application/octet-stream', i.e.. arbitrary binary data.
* @param string $filename A file name or full path, does not need to exist as a file
// In case the path is a URL, strip any query string before getting extension
* Drop-in replacement for pathinfo(), but multibyte-safe, cross-platform-safe, old-version-safe.
* Works similarly to the one in PHP >= 5.2.0
* @param string $path A filename or path, does not need to exist as a file
* or a string name to return only the specified piece, allows 'filename' to work on PHP < 5.2
* You should avoid this function - it's more verbose, less efficient, more error-prone and
* harder to debug than setting properties directly.
* @param string $name The property name to set
* @param mixed $value The value to set the property to
* @TODO Should this not be using the __set() magic function?
* Strip newlines to prevent header injection.
* Normalize line breaks in a string.
* Converts UNIX LF, Mac CR and Windows CRLF line breaks into a single line break format.
* Defaults to CRLF (for message bodies) and preserves consecutive breaks.
* @param string $breaktype What kind of line break to use, defaults to CRLF
* Set the public and private key files and password for S/MIME signing.
// Don't forget to remove WSP around the value
* Create the DKIM header and body in a new message header.
// Signature Timestamp = seconds since 00:00:00 - Jan 1, 1970 (UTC time zone)
// Base64 of packed binary SHA-1 hash of body
* Allows for public read access to 'to' property.
* Allows for public read access to 'cc' property.
* Allows for public read access to 'bcc' property.
* Allows for public read access to 'ReplyTo' property.
* Allows for public read access to 'all_recipients' property.
